selected_quotes: Lipid Profiles and APOE4 Allele Impact Midlife Cognitive Decline in #HIV+ Men on ART (open access)

citation.abstract:
Dyslipidemia and Apolipoprotein E4 (APOE ϵ4) allele are risk factors for age-related cognitive decline, but how these risks are modified by HIV infection is unclear.
 In a longitudinal nested study from the Multicenter AIDS Cohort Study, 273 HIV-1 infected (HIV+) men age 50-65 years with baseline HIV RNA <400 copies/ml and on continuous antiretroviral therapy (ART) in ≥95% of follow-up visits were matched by sociodemographic variables to 516 HIV- controls. The association between lipid markers (total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein (LDL), high-density lipoprotein (HDL), and triglycerides), APOE genotype, and cognitive decline in HIV infection was examined using mixed-effects models.
 The median baseline age of participants was 51, 81% were white, and 89% had education >12 years. HIV+ men had similar baseline total cholesterol and LDL, but lower HDL and higher triglycerides than controls (P<0.001). Higher cholesterol and LDL were associated with faster rates of cognitive decline (P<0.01), while higher HDL attenuated decline (P=0.02) in HIV+ men. In HIV+ men with elevated cholesterol, statin use was associated with a slower estimated rate of decline (P=0.02). APOE ϵ4 genotype accelerated cognitive decline in HIV+ but not HIV- men (P=0.01), with trajectories diverging from HIV- ϵ4 carriers after age 50. Cholesterol levels did not modify the association of ϵ4 genotype with decline (P=0.9).
 Elevated cholesterol and APOE ϵ4 genotype are independent risk factors for cognitive decline in ART-adherent HIV+ men over age 50. Treatment of dyslipidemia may be an effective strategy to reduce cognitive decline in older HIV+ individuals.
citation.title: Lipid Profiles and APOE4 Allele Impact Midlife Cognitive Decline in HIV-Infected Men on Antiretroviral Therapy

news.title: antiretroviral therapy and apoe4 genotype in combination may expedite cognitive decline for hiv positive men
news.summary: Men over the age of 50 who have human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and who are adherent to an antiretroviral therapy (ART) regimen are at risk for cognitive decline, according to the results of a recent study.
